unnormalised: Navigating parenthood is a rollercoaster, isn’t it? One minute you’re celebrating a tiny victory like baby Aanya finally sleeping through the night (well, almost!), and the next, you're Googling frantically at 3 AM because she has a fever of 102°F. That's where the wonderful world of pediatrics comes in, a field I've become intimately familiar with since becoming a mum.
normalised: Navigating parenthood is a rollercoaster, isn’t it? One minute you’re celebrating a tiny victory like baby Aanya finally sleeping through the night, well, almost, and the next, you're Googling frantically at three A-M because she has a fever of one hundred and two degree Fahrenheit. That's where the wonderful world of pediatrics comes in, a field I've become intimately familiar with since becoming a mum.

unnormalised: Our journey started with Dr. Mehra, a pediatrician recommended by almost everyone in our building society. Her clinic in Bandra was always bustling, a testament to her reputation. The first time we took Aanya there for her 6-week check-up, I was a nervous wreck. I had a mental checklist of a million questions, from vaccination schedules to the best way to deal with colic.
normalised: Our journey started with Doctor Mehra, a pediatrician recommended by almost everyone in our building society. Her clinic in Bandra was always bustling, a testament to her reputation. unnormalised: Dr. Mehra, bless her heart, answered each one patiently. She explained that Aanya needed her BCG vaccine and the first dose of the OPV on 15/07/2023. She even showed me how to properly burp her after feeds to minimize the dreaded spit-up, a life-saver, honestly!
normalised: Doctor Mehra, bless her heart, answered each one patiently. She explained that Aanya needed her B-C-G vaccine and the first dose of the O-P-V on fifteenth July two thousand and twenty three. She even showed me how to properly burp her after feeds to minimize the dreaded spit-up, a life-saver, honestly!

unnormalised: Then came the episode with the mysterious rash. Aanya woke up one morning covered in tiny red bumps. My heart leaped into my throat. I immediately thought it was chickenpox, even though she hadn't been exposed to anyone with it. I called Dr. Mehra’s clinic panicking.
normalised: Then came the episode with the mysterious rash. Aanya woke up one morning covered in tiny red bumps. My heart leaped into my throat. I immediately thought it was chickenpox, even though she hadn't been exposed to anyone with it. I called Doctor Mehra’s clinic panicking.

unnormalised: Thankfully, the receptionist managed to squeeze us in for an appointment that afternoon. After a thorough examination, Dr. Mehra diagnosed it as a simple allergic reaction, likely from a new brand of baby wipes I’d tried. She prescribed a mild antihistamine, Cetirizine 2.5mg, and reassured me it would clear up within 24 hours. And it did!
normalised: Thankfully, the receptionist managed to squeeze us in for an appointment that afternoon. After a thorough examination, Doctor Mehra diagnosed it as a simple allergic reaction, likely from a new brand of baby wipes I’d tried. She prescribed a mild antihistamine, Cetirizine two point five milligram, and reassured me it would clear up within twenty four hours. And it did!

unnormalised: Another memorable incident involved a nasty bout of bronchiolitis. It was during the peak of monsoon in Mumbai, and the air was thick with humidity. Aanya developed a cough and was having trouble breathing. Her pediatrician quickly prescribed some nebulization treatments with Duolin, and we were instructed to administer it every 4 hrs. Dr. Mehra also advised keeping her hydrated with ORS (oral rehydration solution) and monitoring her fever.

Aanya developed a cough and was having trouble breathing. Her pediatrician quickly prescribed some nebulization treatments with Duolin, and we were instructed to administer it every four hours. Doctor Mehra also advised keeping her hydrated with O-R-S, oral rehydration solution, and monitoring her fever.

unnormalised: Through all these ups and downs, what I've learned is that finding the right pediatrician is paramount. Someone who not only has the medical expertise but also the patience and empathy to guide you through those nerve-wracking early years. Someone who can calmly explain that a fever of 38.5°C isn’t always an emergency and that most childhood illnesses are just a rite of passage.

unnormalised: And it's not just about the doctor; it's also about the support system. Joining a mum's group online or in person can be incredibly helpful. Sharing experiences, swapping tips, and simply knowing you're not alone in your struggles can make all the difference. My friend Priya, whose son Aryan is a few months older than Aanya, has been my rock. She’s always there to answer my frantic late-night messages with words of wisdom and encouragement.

unnormalised: Parenting, especially with a sick child, can be isolating. But remember, you're not alone. There's a whole community of parents and healthcare professionals ready to support you. Trust your instincts, seek expert advice, and most importantly, cherish those precious moments with your little one, even when they're covered in rashes or coughing up a storm.

unnormalised: So, take a deep breath, mama. You're doing a great job. And remember, Dr. Mehra is just a phone call away! In the end, we got through the bronchiolitis and numerous other childhood illnesses and she's now a perfectly healthy toddler.
